column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/shaq-barrett-wants-another-year/|Shaq Barrett Wants Another Year|So Bucs sacks king Shaq Barrett returned to Tampa Bay two months ago under desperate circumstances. The Bucs were desperate for a spark at edge rush and Shaq decided to unretire. He was welcomed back with open arms and made a few bucks over the final few weeks of the season. That doesn’t mean Shaq produced. He got 17 total snaps over the last two games (including playoffs) and didn’t show much. Still
column2: his impact was felt inside One Buc Palace
column3: Bucs GM Jason Licht said yesterday at the NFL Scouting Combine. “Ahh
column4: it was great. He was great with the young players
column5: ” Licht said of Shaq. “It was like having another coach. Shaq is one of the best
column6: one of the best all-time.” With energy in his voice
column7: Licht added that Shaq could return next season. He’ll turn 33 in November. “We’ll never close the door on Shaq
column8: ” Licht said. “We’ll see where that goes. We never close the door on Shaq.” Joe asked Licht if Shaq wants back in
column9: and Licht quickly replied that Shaq indeed wants to wear pewter and red in 2025

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/quantifying-the-glory-days/|Quantifying The Glory Days|BY IRA KAUFMAN Jason Licht just used an interesting word to describe the state of the Buccaneers. Appearing at the NFL Combine in Indianapolis
column2: the veteran GM said Tampa Bay is an “ascending” franchise. To all of the Todd Bowles skeptics out there
column3: Licht’s label appears ludicrous. The Bowles bashers see a team stuck in the mud
column4: spinning its wheels even as the Bucs have owned the NFC South since 2021. Upon further review
column5: Licht’s assessment hardly ranks as an overstatement. After all
column6: the Bucs have improved from an 8-9 finish in 2022 to 9-8
column7: and then 10-7 last season. That doesn’t include the 2023 team’s rout of the Eagles in the opening playoff round. Do you know how many of the NFL’s 32 clubs have added to their win total in each of the past two seasons? Only four — the Bucs
column9: Packers and Broncos. That’s a short list
column10: backing up Licht’s claim that Tampa Bay is a franchise on the rise. It’s also a young club poised for a serious playoff run if the offseason goes Licht’s way. Every team churns the bottom of the roster every year. That’s life in the NFL
column11: but the transformation of the Bucs since the 2020 championship season has been downright remarkable. Here are the starters from the Super Bowl team
column12: noting that Vita Vea was limited to only five games due to a fractured ankle: OFFENSE    DEFENSE Tom Brady   Will Gholston Mike Evans   Ndamukong Suh Chris Godwin   Rakeem Nunez-Roches Antonio Brown   Shaq Barrett Rob Gronkowski   Lavonte David Ronald Jones   Devin White Donovan Smith   Jason Pierre-Paul Ali Marpet   Carlton Davis Ryan Jensen   Sean Murphy-Bunting Alex Cappa   Jordan Whitehead Tristan Wirfs   Antoine Winfield Jr. There’s a decent chance the team that lines up for Tampa Bay’s 2025 opener will feature only three or four starters from the championship roster. Godwin
column13: Gholston and Barrett are unrestricted free agents. David is pondering retirement at the age of 35. The Bucs just waved goodbye to Whitehead. Even if you count Vea as a 2020 starter
column14: the only sure players back from the Super Bowl team are Vea
column18: is called a massive overhaul in a relatively short period of time. Is there any compelling reason to think the 2025 Bucs are going to fall on their keysters? Not really
column19: unless you factor in a potential serious injury to Baker Mayfield. Licht has consistently added high-character players and Todd Bowles has forged a tight locker room. There are more reasons to believe this franchise will continue to ascend rather than decline. Mayfield’s in his prime
column20: the offensive line is young and second-year back Bucky Irving is a 40-yard run waiting to happen. The offseason priorities are obvious — defense
column22: defense. The Bucs have the wherewithal and the motivation to give Bowles dynamic additions for his side of the ball. Fans welcome the news that Bowles is focused on sharpening Tampa Bay’s game management acumen. It’s not a stretch to suggest these are glory days for Buc fans. Five consecutive years of postseason play is a record stretch of relevance for a franchise that will celebrate its 50th year this fall. In the lexicon of sports
column23: “ascending” is a beautiful word. Embrace it

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/you-just-cant-show-up-like-youre-playing-playstation/|“You Just Can’t Show Up Like You’re Playing PlayStation”|So why was the AdventHamstring Training Center (One Buc Palace) a borderline M*A*S*H unit with all the injuries the Bucs had last year? Players were dropping like flies in 2024. Antoine Winfield got hurt in Week 1 and was a shell of his All-Pro self. The secondary was riddled with injuries. A lot of folks immediately blame the Bucs for not doing (whatever) to prevent injuries. Of course
column2: there was some howling for Bucs trainers to get run. Bucs coach Todd Bowles stuck up for his medical staff this week at the combine in Indianapolis. “Two years ago
column3: we had the same schedule; we were one of the healthiest teams in the league
column5: we had the same schedule and we were one of the most hurt teams in the league. “It is something you look at and check
column6: but you can’t make sense of it now. Obviously
column7: you want to do things better so they don’t get hurt. “When we did it right
column8: we were praised for it. Then we do it right again [with the same schedule] and get bashed for it with injuries.” Bowles does know one solution is not acceptable. The Bucs
column10: could go full-blown underwear football in all practices. No chance

column70: ""post"": ""Tom Brady\u2019s ability to stay injury free had more than pliability & a great diet to do with it. He didn\u2019t take a lot of sacks because he got rid of the ball so quickly and had really good vision in the pocket when he didn\u2019t release it right away. He wasn\u2019t going to juke a lot of people but he knew where to step to avoid the pocket collapse. He also didn\u2019t do the crazy runs Baker does (granted he did do two of them from what I remember\u2026 but they were very rare) since he just didn\u2019t have that kind of ability. He was a pocket pastor and knew his limitations. But Tom\u2019s riskiest move was the quarterback sneak every now and then. He was smart/savvy on many levels about his health and injuries.""

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/slam-dunk-josh-grizzard/|“Slam Dunk” Josh Grizzard|Rookie Bucs offensive coordinator Josh Grizzard is a protégé of Dolphins offensive guru Mike McDaniel
column2: so Joe made sure to get private time with McDaniel this week at the NFL Combine in Indianapolis.  Joe already shared McDaniel talking about Grizzard’s preparation for securing a high-profile playcaller gig at just 34 years old. Today
column3: it’ll be what McDaniel saw in Grizzard when he took over the Dolphins program in 2022 at 38 years old. Grizzard was a young holdover from the Brian Flores regime
column4: but McDaniel didn’t send him packing like often happens when a new head coach arrives. “It goes back to
column6: in my reflection of my career
column7: I’m not here if I didn’t have the fortune of being around Mike Shanahan
column9: ” McDaniel said. “So I was very fortunate in my situation. As a new head coach
column10: you evaluate a situation and you see a guy with talent that maybe wasn’t afforded the same opportunity. “So it was pretty easy to keep [Grizzard] on because he had the work ethic and the desire
column11: and honestly I thought he would really do well being able to learn our system. And he’s absolutely taken that and run with it. That’s why he was a for sure slam dunk in my opinion to follow Liam Coen. So I’m really fired up for him and can’t wait to see what they do.” It’s worth noting that Grizzard and McDaniel played football for Yale University but not at the same time. Surely they must have bonded through their shared life experience
column12: but Grizzard didn’t stick through three head coaches in Miami because he’s an Ivy League grad. In fact
column13: McDaniel never even mentioned Yale to Joe. The “for sure slam dunk” description by McDaniel really struck Joe. If Grizzard really is a hidden gem

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/winning-with-jason-licht-part-iii-a-victory-lap/|Winning With Jason Licht (Part III) — “A Victory Lap”|All this week at the NFL Combine
column2: high-ranking team suits have been plotting
column5: misdirecting and investigating for the start of free agency in 11 short days. So Joe thought this would be a great time to roll out a multi-part series on Buccaneers Ring of Honor general manager Jason Licht.  Licht’s made many defining moves that turned the Bucs into a Super Bowl champ and a lasting contender that has since won four consecutive division titles. During a private sitdown last year
column6: Joe asked new Raiders general manager John Spytek
column8: to field Joe’s questions on all things Licht. Spytek and Licht were very competitive inside One Buc Palace when it came to scouting and player evaluation. They would make strong their cases for players and dig in — playfully and professionally — when they didn’t get the same level of agreement from the other guy. Asked to name the best Licht draft pick
column9: meaning a standout player that Spytek would put in Licht’s personal win column
column10: he named iconic Bucs receiver Chris Godwin without hesitation. Spytek and the scouting staff liked Godwin
column12: but it was Licht who was much deeper love and on board the Godwin train early in the scouting process. “Chris Godwin was Jason’s guy from the start
column13: ” Spytek said. “And then the Rose Bowl happened; he played a fantastic Rose Bowl. Jason kind of did a victory lap on us like
column14: ‘Told you guys.’ The more time we spent with Chris
column15: he became exactly the guy that you guys see. “I just think Jason deserves a ton of credit for that. Godwin’s going to retire as the second-best Bucs receiver of all-time behind a first-ballot Hall of Famer.” What a third-round pick Godwin was
column16: the 11th receiver taken in the 2017 NFL Draft. And guess who agrees with Spytek? Some guy named Mike Evans. Joe asked the same question of Evans and he pointed to Godwin
column17: too. “People don’t realize what an ultimate pro he is
column18: ” Evans said of Godwin. “I’m not saying he’s a better receiver than me
column19: but I’ve learned a ton from him in all aspects of the game
column20: really from Day 1.” In a future piece in this series
column21: Joe will share the words of someone who disagrees with Spytek and Evans on this subject
column22: and tells a very intriguing draft-night story. column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/bucs-get-dinged-on-nflpa-report-card/|Bucs Get Dinged On NFLPA Report Card|The nuns would be peeved at Joe. If Joe got this low of a grade on something in school
column2: Joe would have to stick out a hand so a sexually frustrated nun with a wooden pointer would whack Joe’s palm — provided Joe didn’t get punched by a priest first. The NFLPA pumped out its annual team report card
column3: conveniently timed when all #NFLMedia is clustered into one building in downtown Indianapolis. Each team was graded on how it treats its players whether players perceive the team to be a good employer in various categories. In an overall grade
column4: the Bucs were ranked No. 27 in the league. First
column5: the highlights: The strength coaches got an A. Wrote the NFLPA: “100% of players report that they get an individualized plan from their strength coaching staff
column6: one of the three teams in the league with a perfect score.” Also
column7: the Bucs have good grub. They got a B+ grade for the team’s nutritionist/dietician. The training staff was graded better with a B. Weight room got a B as well
column8: and Bucs coach Todd Bowles got a B+. Maybe having edge rushers drop back into coverage so much came back to bite Todd Bowles
column9: preventing him from getting an A? Overall
column10: Bucs players gave their locker room a “C” and cited bad plumbing and a persistent stench in the locker room. Will that be gone with Joe Tryon-Shoyinka’s expected departure? (Joe once remembers Tristan Wirfs trying to find the source of a scent he claimed smelled like baby powder
column11: and he believed one of the members of the Tampa Bay pen and mic club wore some weird cologne that smelled like it.) In only one category did the Bucs get a grade worse than a C- and that was ownership. Team Glazer received a D-. Among the reasons for the low score was a perceived lack of investment in facilities and allegedly not contributing to the winning culture of the team. Joe isn’t sure about the latter.
